Award.AwardTitle: Pathways to Graduate School and Professional Careers in the Mathematical Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Pathways to Graduate School and Careers in the Mathematical Sciences project will increase the number of trained scholars ready to enter the STEM workforce. Scholarship support will be offered to students in South Texas Rio Grande Valley pursuing professional careers in fields requiring a significant background in Mathematics. The effort's broader impacts lie in the creation of infrastructure for a necessary and permanent South Texas bridge to graduate school and professional careers in the mathematical sciences.

The Pathways project will mentor University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) undergraduates through the vital period from their freshman year to the completion of a Masters degree. Financial and academic support will be provided to 22 students within UTRGV's 5-year BS/MS degree in mathematics. The objective of the project is to prepare students for careers in mathematics, statistics, and related fields through a close support network, early involvement in research, and an emphasis on graduate degree attainment. The recruitment, retention, mentoring, development, and academic support installed through this coordinated approach will provide a solid foundation for future STEM scholars in the Rio Grande Valley. Program assessment and data collected will provide evidence to inform strategies for increasing the success of mathematics mentoring programs at other Minority Serving Institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The program focused on students in South Texas pursuing graduate school and professional careers in fields requiring a significant background in Mathematics. Major goals of this project included increasing the number of research-trained scholars ready to enter the STEM workforce. 

Significant impacts include a high retention rate and graduation rate among the cohort, a high rate of student applications to summer research programs, a significant proportion of S-STEM recipient applications to graduate school, and a high employment rate in disciplines requiring advanced mathematics. These outcomes are in line with the intellectual merit of the original proposal and are fruits of the program's persistent promotion of research opportunities, careers, and graduate school. The emphasis on connecting students and research mentors has resulted in multiple prestigious peer reviewed journal articles coauthored with students. The increase in the number of research workshops designed to recruit the S-STEM cohort impacted the college as a whole and students in other STEM colleges within the university. The high application rate to summer research opportunities in the latter years of the grant was aided in part by research initiatives such as the UT-LSAMP program, another important NSF supported initiative.

Other impacts include increased GPAs among math majors in the cohort; an increase in the number of undergraduates that go on to pursue Master's degrees; and improvements to support structures for particularly challenging courses. The support structures developed for the S-STEM scholars will have had a significant sustained impact on the achievement of students at UTRGV.

The program positioned students to start excellent careers in mathematics intensive fields. Some were accepted into prestigious graduate programs or careers at governmental agencies.  Peer reviewed research published in prestigious journals gave students a considerable advantage in their job searches. The research was cultivated by activities that increased collaboration between students and faculty and events that increased student applications to summer research experiences. The academic support and mentoring helped students make informed decisions about career choices and graduate school. The research experiences and comprehensive mentoring architecture put career opportunities and graduate school in the spotlight. 

The program afforded opportunities to students at critical transition points. A large proportion of the students in the cohort were transfer students from local community colleges. These students proved to be among the most successful, with many enrolling in graduate school in mathematics and related fields. Some of the students completed degree requirements early. The overall success of the cohort indicates that targeting talented community college students and communicating research opportunities early can lead to marked increases in on-time graduation and increases in the number of students obtaining immediate employment in STEM disciplines or attending graduate school in mathematics intensive fields. 

By increasing mentorship of students in math intensive disciplines, the program cultivated increased collaboration and communication among STEM departments within the university. These partnerships have promoted student success and raised the visibility of research opportunities. The increased mentoring opened channels between the departments and academic advisors. This allowed students in the cohort to accelerate their college education by placing into advanced mathematics courses. The benefits apply to both the funded S-STEM and students not in the cohort.

The broader impacts of the current program are important, especially in areas such as the lower Rio Grande Valley with a comparatively large proportion of young people and a high proportion of underrepresented groups in STEM. This includes a high proportion of Hispanic students and women. Of the 45 active students at the end of the program, 40% are female and over 84% identify as Hispanic. The number of women and Hispanics impacted by the program is well above their representation in STEM fields nationwide.

Some of the students impacted by the program are on track to become high school STEM teachers. This group benefited from the seminars and research activities by seeing mathematics in action and by becoming involved with the research of faculty members. The future educators in the cohort will draw on these experiences throughout their careers. The long-term impact includes generations of future students who will view mathematics as an engaging and dynamic discipline that drives scientific progress. This is critical as the nation seeks to educate future students to become world leaders in science and technology.

The outreach and recruitment for the program was broad and improved public knowledge of opportunities in mathematics. In particular, presentations to the Texas Sectional Meeting of the Mathematical Association of America reflect efforts to promote STEM education along several dimensions. The program is a template for academic support and mentoring that serves as a national model.
